title: Isotropic manifold
summary: In mathematics, an isotropic manifold is a manifold in which the geometry does not depend on directions. Formally, we say that a Riemannian manifold ( M , g ) {\displaystyle (M,g)} is isotropic if for any point p ∈ M {\displaystyle p\in M} and unit vectors v , w ∈ T p M {\displaystyle v,w\in T_{p}M} , there is an isometry φ {\displaystyle \varphi } of M {\displaystyle M} with φ ( p ) = p {\displaystyle \varphi (p)=p} and φ ∗ ( v ) = w {\displaystyle \varphi _{\ast }(v)=w} . Every connected isotropic manifold is homogeneous, i.e. for any p , q ∈ M {\displaystyle p,q\in M} there is an isometry φ {\displaystyle \varphi } of M {\displaystyle M} with φ ( p ) = q . {\displaystyle \varphi (p)=q.} This can be seen by considering a geodesic γ : [ 0 , 2 ] → M {\displaystyle \gamma :[0,2]\to M} from p {\displaystyle p} to q {\displaystyle q} and taking the isometry which fixes γ ( 1 ) {\displaystyle \gamma (1)} and maps γ ′ ( 1 ) {\displaystyle \gamma '(1)} to − γ ′ ( 1 ) . {\displaystyle -\gamma '(1).}
